case_name: Workmen v. Eagle Rolling Mills Ltd., Kumardhubi Engineering Works Ltd. and Kumardhubi Fire Clay and Silica Works Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 721-723 of 1962 were filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 721-723 of 1962. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 1, 1961, of the Pat

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 1, 1961, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 1167, 1122 and 1235 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 1, 1961, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 1167, 1122 and 1235 of 1960.

facts.text: Appellants are workmen of Eagle Rolling Mills Ltd., Kumardhubi Engineering Works Ltd., and Kumardhubi Fire Clay and Silica Works Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants who are the workmen of the three respondent companycerns, the Eagle Rolling Mills Ltd., the Kumardhubi Engineering Works Ltd., and Kumardhubi Fire Clay and Silica Works Ltd., respectively,

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions before the Patna High Court alleging section 13 of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 is invalid as it contravenes Art. 14 and suffers from excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: By their writ petitions filed before the Patna High Court, the appellants who are the workmen of the three respondent companycerns, the Eagle Rolling Mills Ltd., the Kumardhubi Engineering Works Ltd., and Kumardhubi Fire Clay and Silica Works Ltd., respectively, alleged that the impugned section has companytravened Art. 14 of the Constitution, and suffers from the vice of excessive delegation, and as such is invalid.

facts.text: Patna High Court rejected the plea and dismissed the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: These employers were impleaded as respondent No. 1 respectively in the three writ petitions. The High Court has rejected the plea and the writ petitions filed by the appellants have accordingly been dismissed.

facts.text: Respondents No. 1 in all three appeals are under the management of M/s. Bird. Co. Ltd., through a General Manager.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that respondents No. 1 in all the three appeals are under the management of M s. Bird. Co. Ltd., through a General Manager, and the appellants are their workmen.

facts.text: Appellants as workmen were getting satisfactory medical benefits of a very high order free of any charge.

anchor.surface_text: As such workmen, the appellants were getting satisfactory medical benefits of a very high order free of any charge. Respondent No. 1 in each appeal maintained a wellfurnished hospital with provision for 60 permanent beds for the workmen, their families and their dependents.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 in each appeal maintained a well-furnished hospital with provision for 60 permanent beds for the workmen, their families and their dependents.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 in each appeal maintained a wellfurnished hospital with provision for 60 permanent beds for the workmen, their families and their dependents. The main grievance made by the appellants is that as a result of s. 1 3  of the Act, the appellants have number to be companytent with medical benefits of a less satisfactory nature.

facts.text: Appellants' main grievance is that as a result of s. 13 of the Act, they have to be content with medical benefits of a less satisfactory nature.

anchor.surface_text: The main grievance made by the appellants is that as a result of s. 1 3  of the Act, the appellants have number to be companytent with medical benefits of a less satisfactory nature. That is why they challenged the validity of the impugned section and companytest the propriety and legality of the numberification issued under it.

facts.text: On 22nd August 1960, respondent No. 3 issued a notification under section 1(3) appointing 28th August 1960 as the date on which some provisions of the Act come into force in certain areas of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: On the 22nd August, 1960, respondent No. 3 issued a numberification under section 1, sub-section  3  appointing the 28th August, 1960 as the date on which some provisions of the Act should companye into force in certain areas of the State of Bihar.

facts.text: The area in which the appellants are working came within the scope of the Act by the notification.

anchor.surface_text: By this numberification, the area in which the appellants are working came within the scope of the Act.

facts.text: Chief Executive Officer of respondent No. 1 informed the appellants on 25th August 1960 that medical benefits under the Act will cease from the appointed day.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the said numberification, the Chief Executive Officer of respondent No. 1 informed the appellants on the 25th August, 1960 that the medical benefits including indoor and outdoor treatment upto the extent admissible under the Act will cease to be provided to insurable person-, from the appointed day.

facts.text: A notice was issued and published by the Chief Executive Officer informing about cessation of prior medical benefits.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice in that behalf was duly issued and published by the said Officer. Similar numberices were issued indicating to the appellants that medical benefits would thereafter be governed by the relevant provisions of the Act and number by the arrangements which had been made earlier by respondent No. 1 in that behalf.

facts.text: Judgment of the Supreme Court delivered on February 26, 1964 by GAJENDRAGADKAR. C.J.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary, Attorney-General, N. S. Bindra, V. Mahajan and B. R. G. K. Achar, for respondents Nos. 2 and 3. February 26, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR. C.J.-The short question which arises in these appeals by special leave is whether section 1 3  of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948  No. 34 of 1948   hereinafter called the Act  is invalid.

facts.text: Employees State Insurance Corporation and Union of India impleaded as respondents 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: To these writ petitions as well as to the appeals, the Employees State Insurance Corporation and the Union of India have been impleaded as respondents 2 and 3 respectively.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that section 1(3) of the Act is not invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must hold that the impugned section 1  3  of the Act is number shown to be companystitutionally invalid.

facts.text: High Court held that notices issued by respondent No. 1 were not to be considered under Art. 226, but under Industrial Disputes Act s.10 or ESI Act ss.74,75.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that the question as to whether the numberices and circulars issued by respondent No. 1 were invalid, companyld number be companysidered under Art. 226 of the Constitution that is a matter which can be appropriately raised in the form of a dispute by the appellants under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeals fail and are dismissed.

facts.text: Three appeals proceed on similar facts and raise identical question of law, heard together.

anchor.surface_text: The three appeals proceed on similar facts and raise an identical question of law and have, therefore, been heard together.

facts.text: Appellants challenged the notification issued under s.13.

anchor.surface_text: That is why they challenged the validity of the impugned section and companytest the propriety and legality of the numberification issued under it.

facts.text: Chief Executive Officer issued notices indicating medical benefits governed by Act, not prior arrangements.

anchor.surface_text: Similar numberices were issued indicating to the appellants that medical benefits would thereafter be governed by the relevant provisions of the Act and number by the arrangements which had been made earlier by respondent No. 1 in that behalf.

facts.text: Appellants contended before High Court that notices by respondent No.1 were invalid.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by the appellants before the High Court that these numberices were invalid and should be struck down.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirmed High Court's finding on remedy for notices under Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, without expressing any opinion on the merits of the companytention, we would companyfirm the finding of the High Court that the proper remedy which is available to the appellants to ventilate their grievances in respect of the said numberices and circulars is to take recourse to s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, or seek relief, if possible, under sections 74 and 75 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must hold that the impugned section 1  3  of the Act is number shown to be companystitutionally invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.1(3) constitutes conditional legislation, not delegated legislation; alternatively, any delegation is guided by the Act's preamble, policy, scheme, definitions, and provisions; analogous to upheld powers in precedents like Queen v. Burah, Edward Mills, etc.

holdings.text: s.1(3) is conditional legislation and not an instance of delegated legislation

anchor.surface_text: Section 1 3  is really number an illustration of delegated legislation at all it is what can be properly described as companyditional legislation. The Act has prescribed a self-contained companye in regard to the insurance of the, employees companyered by it several remedial measures which the Legislature thought it necessary to enforce in regard to such workmen have been specifically dealt with and appropriate provisions have been made to carry out the policy of the Act as laid down in its relevant sections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The Act lays down a complete code with policy in relevant sections; bringing into force is conditional upon notification fulfilling legislative judgment on place, etc., as in Queen v. Burah.

holdings.text: Even if element of delegation in s.1(3), it is not excessive as guided by Act's provisions

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that there is an element of delegation, the plea is equally unsustainable, because there is enough guidance given by the relevant provisions of the Act and the very scheme of the Act itself. The preamble to the Act shows that it was passed because the legislature thought it expedient to provide for certain benefits to employees in case of sickness, maternity and employment injury and. to make provision for certain other matters in relation thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Guidance from preamble's policy, definitions in s.2, scheme across chapters (II-VIII); practical needs of phased implementation; consistent with modern welfare legislation and precedents like Minimum Wages Act s.27.

holdings.text: Grievances regarding notices and circulars issued by employer ceasing prior medical benefits not cognizable under Art.226; proper remedy under Industrial Disputes Act s.10 or ESI Act ss.74,75

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, without expressing any opinion on the merits of the companytention, we would companyfirm the finding of the High Court that the proper remedy which is available to the appellants to ventilate their grievances in respect of the said numberices and circulars is to take recourse to s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, or seek relief, if possible, under sections 74 and 75 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.226 powers wide but do not extend to industrial disputes; specific statutory mechanisms provided for such grievances.

anchor.surface_text: 1869 in Queen v. Burah 1 , can be said with equal justification about the powers companyferred on the Central Government by s. 1 3 . Said Lord Selborne in that case Their Lordships think that it is a fallacy to speak of the powers thus companyferred upon the Lieutenant-Governor  large as they undoubtedly are  as if, when they were exercised, the efficacy of the acts done under them would be due to arty other legislative authority than that of the Governor-General in Council. Their whole operation is directly and immediately under and by virtue of this Act  XXII of 1869  itself. The proper Legislature has exercised its judgment as, to place, person, laws, powers and the result of that judgment has been to legislate companyditionally as to all these things. The Conditions having been fulfilled, the legislation, is number absolute. That is the first answer to the plea raised by Mr. Chatterjee.

precedents.cited_proposition: powers conferred on the Lieutenant-Governor by notification under Act 22 of 1869 constitute conditional legislation and not delegated legislation
precedents.cited_holding: Their Lordships think that it is a fallacy to speak of the powers thus conferred upon the Lieutenant-Governor large as they undoubtedly are as if, when they were exercised, the efficacy of the acts done under them would be due to any other legislative authority than that of the Governor-General in Council. Their whole operation is directly and immediately under and by virtue of this Act XXII of 1869 itself. The proper Legislature has exercised its judgment as to place, person, laws, powers and the result of that judgment has been to legislate conditionally as to all these things. The Conditions having been fulfilled, the legislation is absolute.

precedents.citation: Edward Mills Co. Ltd., Beawar and Others v. The State of Ajmer and Another 1

anchor.surface_text: In the Edward Mills Co. Ltd., Beawar and Others v. The State of Ajmer and Another 1 , this Court repelled the challenge to the validity of s. 27 of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948  No. XI of 1948 , whereby power had been given to the appropriate Government to add to either part of the schedule any employment in respect of which it was of opinion that minimum wages shall be fixed by giving numberification in a particular manner, and it was provided that on the issue of the numberification, the scheme shall, in its application to the State, be deemed to be amended accordingly.

precedents.case_name: Edward Mills Co Ltd Beawar v State of Ajmer
precedents.cited_proposition: delegation under s. 27 of Minimum Wages Act allowing government to add employments by notification is permissible and not excessive
precedents.cited_holding: there was an element of delegation implied in the provisions of s. 27, for the legislature, in a sense, authorised another body specified by it to do something which it might do itself but it was held that such delegation was not unwarranted and unconstitutional and it did not exceed the limits of permissible delegation

precedents.citation: M s. Bhikusa Yamasa Kshatriya and Another v. Sangamner Akola Taluka Bidi Kamgar Union and Others 2

anchor.surface_text: To the same effect are the recent decisions of this Court in M s. Bhikusa Yamasa Kshatriya and Another v. Sangamner Akola Taluka Bidi Kamgar Union and Others 2 , and Bhikusa Yamasa Kshatriya  P  Ltd. v. Union of India and Another 3 . Therefore, we must hold that the impugned section 1  3  of the Act is not shown to be constitutionally invalid.

precedents.cited_proposition: no excessive delegation in similar welfare legislation schemes

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that there is an element of delegation, the plea is equally unsustainable, because there is enough guidance given by the relevant provisions of the Act and the very scheme of the Act itself. The preamble to the Act shows that it was passed because the legislature thought it expedient to provide for certain benefits to employees in case of sickness, maternity and employment injury and. to make provision for certain other matters in relation thereto.
The result is, the appeals fail and are dismissed.
